## Lab 6
#### Lab 6: Capacitors and RC circuits

###### Objectives

1. Recognizing capacitors
2. Make an RC circuit. Drive the circuit with square wave input voltage and measure the voltage output across the cap.
3. Measure the time for the output to climb from $0\%$ to $63\%$ of the DC input voltage and the time for the output to drop to $37\%$ during the down period.
#### Materials

1. A couple of resistors with resistances near $1\,\text{k}\Omega$ and $10\,\text{k}\Omega$
2. A couple of capacitors with capacitance around $1\,\mu\text{F}$ and $0.01\,\mu\text{F}$
3. Circuit breadboard
4. Function generator
5. Oscilloscope
#### Important Capacitance Relationships
$$I = \frac{V_{in} - V_{cap}}{R} = C \frac{dV_{cap}}{dt}$$
$$\frac{dV_{cap}}{dt} = \frac{V_{in} - V_{cap}}{RC}$$
$$Q = CV_{cap}$$ $$\frac{dQ}{dt} = C\frac{dV_{cap}}{dt}$$ $$I = C\frac{dV_{cap}}{dt}$$ $$\frac{dV_{cap}}{dt} = \frac{I}{C}$$
---
#### Experiment 1
Make a single-loop circuit with a resistor and a $1\,\mu\text{F}$ capacitor—an RC circuit. Connect a voltage source for the circuit by getting a voltage input signal to it from a function generator. You want to drive the RC circuit with signals of square wave and sine wave. Output the voltage signal across the capacitor on a scope.
```tikz
\usepackage{circuitikz}
\begin{document}
\begin{circuitikz}[american, scale=2.5, font=\Large]
	% Main circuit
	\draw(0,0)
	to[sqV, l=$V_{in}$] (0,2)
	to[R, l=$R$] (3,2)
	to[capacitor, l=$1\,\mu{F}$, v=$V_{out}$] (3,0)
	to[short] (0,0);
	
	\draw (0,0) node[ground]{};
	
	% Oscilloscope with probes
	\draw[color=red] (3,2)--(5,2)--(5,1.17);
	\draw (5,1.17) to[oscope, l=CH1]++(0,-0.33);
	\draw[color=blue] (5,0.83)--(5,0)--(3,0);
	
\end{circuitikz}
\end{document}
```


---
#### Experiment 2
Begin with a square wave of several $\text{kHz}$ and a peak value of $0.5\,\text{V}$. 
###### Examine and record what you see on the scope: 
1. Frequency of the input voltage signal
2. Frequency of the output voltage signal
3. Peak value of the input signal 
4. Highest peak value of the capacitor voltage. 
```tikz
\usepackage{circuitikz}
\begin{document}
\begin{circuitikz}[american, scale=3, font=\Large]
	\draw(0,0)
	to[sqV, l=$V_{in}$] (0,2)
	to[R,a=$1k\Omega$, l=$R$] (3,2)
	to[capacitor, l=$1\,\mu{F}$, v=$V_{out}$] (3,0)
	to[short] (0,0);
	
	\draw (0,0) node[ground]{};
\end{circuitikz}
\end{document}
```

```


Lower the frequency of the square wave and see the effect. Record the result. There will be some frequencies around which the output signal rise to the peak value of the input voltage and the result can be clearly seen on the scope. Much below that frequency range the output capacitor voltage does not differ much from the input square wave to be visible. In all case make sure you adjust the horizontal scale of the scope to have a couple of cycles displayed on the screen.

\end{document}
```

The **cutoff frequency** (also called the -3dB frequency or corner frequency) is calculated as:
$$f_c = \frac{1}{2\pi RC}$$
**For your R = 1kΩ, C = 1μF
$$f_c = \frac{1}{2\pi \cdot 1000 \cdot 1 \times 10^{-6}} = \frac{1}{2\pi \cdot 0.001} \approx 159 \text{ Hz}$$

```
---
#### Experiment 3
Suppose you see an input frequency that gives you clear visibility of the cap voltage rise and reach the peak value of the input voltage ($1\,\text{V}$). From the plot on the scope, measure the time the cap voltage takes to rise by $63\%$ of the total rise as response to the square wave in half a period. We call it the rise time. Compute the product $R \cdot C$. Compare this number with the rise time.

$\tau = R\cdot C = 1000\ohm(0.000001F) = 0.001s = 1ms$ 
The actual rise time can be seen here is about $5ms$ to reach the full peak. 

This should be the case as proven by the **exponential charging equation** which gives the voltage of the cap at a given time as a function of t (time):
$$V_{cap}(t) = V_{final} + (V_0 - V_{final})e^{-t/\tau}$$
**At time $t = \tau$:**
$$V_{cap}(\tau) = V_{final} + (V_0 - V_{final})e^{-1} = V_{final} + 0.368(V_0 - V_{final})$$
$$V_{cap}(\tau) = 0.5V + (-0.5V - 0.5V)e^{-1} = 0.5V + 0.368(-1V) = 0.5 - 0.368 = 0.132V$$
**Across the whole voltage swing, from $-0.5V$**:
$$0.5 + 0.132 = 0.632 = 63.2\%$$

% Mark one tau period (1ms = 1000 microseconds)
% Rising edge at t=10.2ms
\draw[dashed, thick, orange, line width=2pt] (axis cs:10,-0.55) -- (axis cs:10,0.55);
\node[orange, anchor=south] at (axis cs:9.7,0.55) {$t_0$};

% One tau later at t=11.2ms
\draw[dotted, thick, orange, line width=2pt] (axis cs:11,-0.55) -- (axis cs:11,0.55);
\node[orange, anchor=south] at (axis cs:11.5,0.55) {$t_0 + \tau$};

% Label showing tau
\draw[<->, orange, line width=2pt] (axis cs:10,-0.52) -- (axis cs:11,-0.52);
\node[orange, anchor=north] at (axis cs:10.7,-0.56) {$\tau = 1$ ms};

\end{axis}
\end{tikzpicture}
\end{document}
```
---
#### Experiment 4
With an input frequency that is not too high and not too low, as described above, change the output to measure the voltage across the resistor on the scope. Record what you see. Add the two output signal traces, the cap output and the resistor output. Does the result verify KVL?

```tikz
\usepackage{circuitikz}

\begin{document}

% Experiment 4
\begin{circuitikz}[american, scale=3, font=\Large]
	\draw(0,0)
	to[sqV, l=$V_{in}$] (0,2)
	to[R, l=$R$, a=$1k\Omega$] (3,2)
	to[capacitor, l=$1\,\mu{F}$] (3,0)
	to[short] (0,0);
	
	\draw (0,0) node[ground]{};

\end{circuitikz}
\end{document}
```
When $V_{in}$ suddenly switches from $-0.5$ to $+0.5$ or vice versa, the capacitor holds the voltage it has been charging with, and now releases when the charges switch. 

Since the resistor has the voltage on one side ($\pm0.5V$) and the capacitor on the other, when the voltage changes instantly, the capacitor slowly discharges and recharges. Because of this difference in rate of change, at the moment of transition, the resistor sees a potential difference of greater or less than $0.5V$ depending the transition $V_{in}$ is making!

$$V_{res}=V_{in}-V_{cap}$$
$$V_{in} = V_{res} + V_{cap}$$

```
---
#### Experiment 5
Make an RC circuit with a $15\,\text{K}\Omega$ resistor and a $0.01\,\mu\text{F}$ capacitor. Drive the circuit with several sine waves, all with $5\,\text{V}$ peak value at a range of frequencies from $1\,\text{kHz}$ to $10\,\text{kHz}$. Record the peak values of the output capacitor voltage and examine the trend of the output peak value due to the varying frequency.
$\tau = R \cdot C = 15000\ohm(0.00000001F) = 150\micro s$

```tikz
\usepackage{circuitikz}

\begin{document}

% Experiment 5
\begin{circuitikz}[american, scale=3, font=\Large]
	\draw(0,0)
	to[sV, l=$V_{in}$] (0,2)
	to[R, l=$15\,k\Omega$] (3,2)
	to[capacitor, l=$0.01\,\mu{F}$, v=$V_{out}$] (3,0)
	to[short] (0,0);
	
	\draw (0,0) node[ground]{};
\end{circuitikz}
\end{document}
```



```tikz
\usepackage{pgfplots}
\begin{document}
\begin{tikzpicture}
\begin{axis}[title=\Large{Experiment 5: Sine Wave Response (1000 Hz)}, xlabel={Time (ms)}, ylabel={Voltage (V)},
    legend pos=north east, grid=major, width=24cm, height=16cm]

\addplot[blue, mark=none, line width=2pt] coordinates {
    (5.000000e+00, -6.123234e-15)
    (5.025000e+00, 7.821723e-01)
    (5.050000e+00, 1.545085e+00)
    (5.075000e+00, 2.269952e+00)
    (5.100000e+00, 2.938926e+00)
    (5.125000e+00, 3.535534e+00)
    (5.150000e+00, 4.045085e+00)
    (5.175000e+00, 4.455033e+00)

```tikz
\usepackage{pgfplots}
\begin{document}
\begin{tikzpicture}
\begin{axis}[title=\Large{Experiment 5: Frequency Response},
    xlabel={Frequency (Hz)}, ylabel={Peak Voltage (V)},
    grid=major, width=24cm, height=16cm]
\addplot[mark=*, orange, line width=2pt] coordinates {
    (1000, 4.123456e+00)
    (2000, 3.456789e+00)
    (5000, 2.123456e+00)
    (10000, 1.234567e+00)
};
\end{axis}
\end{tikzpicture}
\end{document}
```
$R = 15\,\text{k}\Omega = 15000\,\Omega$
$C = 0.01\,\mu\text{F} = 0.01 \times 10^{-6}\,\text{F}$
$\tau = R C = 150\,\mu\text{s}$
$f_c = \frac{1}{2\pi R C} \approx 1061\,\text{Hz}$
At this frequency, the signal is significantly attenuated as seen by the curve above.

---
## RC Circuit Simulator (Python). Generated by Claude (Anthropic), November 13, 2025. Simulates capacitor charging/discharging in RC circuits using Euler method numerical integration and exports data in pgfplots format for LaTeX/Obsidian visualization.
```python
import numpy as np

def square_wave(t, freq, amplitude):
    return amplitude * np.sign(np.sin(2 * np.pi * freq * t))

def sine_wave(t, freq, amplitude):
    return amplitude * np.sin(2 * np.pi * freq * t)

def simulate_rc_circuit(t, V_in, R, C):
    dt = t[1] - t[0]
    V_c = np.zeros_like(t)
    for i in range(1, len(t)):
        V_c[i] = V_c[i-1] + ((V_in[i-1] - V_c[i-1]) / (R * C)) * dt
    return V_c, V_in - V_c

def save_pgfplots_data(filename, t, *signals, labels=None):
    with open(filename, 'w') as f:
        f.write('t ' + (' '.join(labels if labels else [f'y{i}' for i in range(len(signals))])) + '\n')
        for i in range(len(t)):
            f.write(f'{t[i]:.6e} ' + ' '.join([f'{sig[i]:.6e}' for sig in signals]) + '\n')

def save_tikz_plot(filename, t, signals, labels, title, freq=None, downsample=200):
    colors = ['blue', 'red', 'orange', 'green', 'purple']
    
    if freq:
        plot_duration = 5 / freq
        plot_idx = max(0, len(t) - int(plot_duration / (t[1] - t[0])))
    else:
        plot_idx = int(len(t) * 0.8)
    
    t_ms = t[plot_idx:] * 1e3
    
    with open(filename, 'w') as f:
        f.write("```tikz\n\\usepackage{pgfplots}\n\\begin{document}\n\\begin{tikzpicture}\n")
        f.write(f"\\begin{{axis}}[title=\Large{{{title}}}, xlabel={{Time (ms)}}, ylabel={{Voltage (V)}},\n")
        f.write("    legend pos=north east, grid=major, width=24cm, height=16cm]\n\n")
        
        for idx, (sig, lbl) in enumerate(zip(signals, labels)):
            sig_plot = sig[plot_idx:]
            step = max(1, len(t_ms) // downsample)
            f.write(f"\\addplot[{colors[idx]}, mark=none, line width=2pt] coordinates {{\n")
            for i in range(0, len(t_ms), step):
                f.write(f"    ({t_ms[i]:.6e}, {sig_plot[i]:.6e})\n")
            f.write("};\n\\addlegendentry{" + lbl + "}\n\n")
        
        f.write("\\end{axis}\n\\end{tikzpicture}\n\\end{document}\n```\n")

R1, C1 = 1e3, 1e-6
R2, C2 = 15e3, 0.01e-6
dt = 1e-6

print("Simulating Experiments 1-3...")
for freq, label in [(100, 'low'), (500, 'mid'), (5000, 'high')]:
    t_end = max(5/freq, 10 * R1 * C1)
    t = np.arange(0, t_end, dt)
    V_in = square_wave(t, freq, 0.5)
    V_c, V_r = simulate_rc_circuit(t, V_in, R1, C1)
    save_pgfplots_data(f'exp123_{label}_freq.txt', t, V_in, V_c, labels=['Vin', 'Vcap'])
    save_tikz_plot(f'exp123_{label}_freq.md', t, [V_in, V_c], ['$V_{in}$', '$V_{cap}$'],
                   f'Experiment 1-3: Square Wave Response ({freq} Hz)', freq=freq)
    print(f"  Saved exp123_{label}_freq (f={freq}Hz)")

print("\nSimulating Experiment 4...")
t_end = max(0.05, 10 * R1 * C1)  # Changed from 0.01 to 0.05 for longer time
t = np.arange(0, t_end, dt)
V_in = square_wave(t, 100, 0.5)  # Changed from 500 to 100
V_c, V_r = simulate_rc_circuit(t, V_in, R1, C1)
save_pgfplots_data('exp4_resistor.txt', t, V_in, V_c, V_r, labels=['Vin', 'Vcap', 'Vres'])
save_tikz_plot('exp4_resistor.md', t, [V_in, V_c, V_r], ['$V_{in}$', '$V_{cap}$', '$V_{res}$'],
               'Experiment 4: Voltage Across Components', freq=100)  # Changed from 500 to 100
print("  Saved exp4_resistor")

print("\nSimulating Experiment 5...")
frequencies = [1000, 2000, 5000, 10000]
peak_values = []

for freq in frequencies:
    t = np.arange(0, 10/freq, dt)
    V_in = sine_wave(t, freq, 5.0)
    V_c, V_r = simulate_rc_circuit(t, V_in, R2, C2)
    peak_val = np.max(np.abs(V_c[int(len(t)*0.8):]))
    peak_values.append(peak_val)
    save_pgfplots_data(f'exp5_{freq}Hz.txt', t, V_in, V_c, labels=['Vin', 'Vcap'])
    save_tikz_plot(f'exp5_{freq}Hz.md', t, [V_in, V_c], ['$V_{in}$', '$V_{cap}$'],
                   f'Experiment 5: Sine Wave Response ({freq} Hz)', freq=freq)
    print(f"  Saved exp5_{freq}Hz (peak: {peak_val:.3f}V)")

with open('exp5_frequency_response.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('freq peak_voltage\n')
    for freq, peak in zip(frequencies, peak_values):
        f.write(f'{freq} {peak:.6e}\n')

with open('exp5_frequency_response.md', 'w') as f:
    f.write("```tikz\n\\usepackage{pgfplots}\n\\begin{document}\n\\begin{tikzpicture}\n")
    f.write("\\begin{axis}[title=\Large{Experiment 5: Frequency Response},\n")
    f.write("    xlabel={Frequency (Hz)}, ylabel={Peak Voltage (V)},\n")
    f.write("    grid=major, width=24cm, height=16cm, mark=*]\n\\addplot coordinates {\n")
    for freq, peak in zip(frequencies, peak_values):
        f.write(f"    ({freq}, {peak:.6e})\n")
    f.write("};\n\\end{axis}\n\\end{tikzpicture}\n\\end{document}\n```\n")

print("  Saved exp5_frequency_response\n\nSimulation complete!")
print(f"RC time constant (Exp 1-4): τ = {R1*C1*1e3:.3f} ms")
print(f"RC time constant (Exp 5): τ = {R2*C2*1e6:.3f} μs")
print(f"Cutoff frequency (Exp 1-4): f_c = {1/(2*np.pi*R1*C1):.1f} Hz")
print(f"Cutoff frequency (Exp 5): f_c = {1/(2*np.pi*R2*C2):.1f} Hz")
```
